meta.title: Taenia solium infection: taeniasis and cysticercosis

content:
Introduction

Taenia solium causes 2 distinct infections in humans:  taeniasis (pork tapeworm) and cysticercosis.  Taeniasis occurs when humans ingest an immature form of the worm in contaminated, undercooked pork meat.  The worm matures in the human digestive tract and releases eggs in the stool.  Although pork tapeworm does not generally cause symptoms, cysticercosis can occur when the eggs are incidentally ingested by the individual (autoinnoculation), household contacts, or members of the community.  The eggs mature into larvae and form cysts in host tissue (eg, brain, ventricles, eye).  Months or years later the cysts degrade, leading to symptoms (eg, new-onset seizures).  T solium is endemic in many parts of Central/South America, sub-Saharan Africa, and Asia.  It primarily occurs in rural areas where sanitation is poor and pigs roam freely.

Risk factors



  • Dietary:  Tapeworm infection occurs due to eating raw or undercooked pork.  Raw pork from endemic areas should be inspected for signs of infection (ie. "grisly" meat) prior to cooking.
  • Poor sanitation and hygiene:  Inadequate sewage disposal practices are present in nearly all endemic areas.  Poor handwashing can lead to autoinoculation or household transmission.
  • Close contact with infected individuals:  Household members of individuals with tapeworm infection are at greatest risk for cysticercosis.

Pathophysiology



Taenasis (tapeworm infection) occurs when humans ingest a scolex, the nob-like head of the worm, in contaminated, undercooked pork.  The scolex attaches to the mucosa in the small intestine using 4 radially arranged suckers and 2 rows of hooks.  Over 1-2 months, the worm grows a flat, ribbon-like body with 800-900 segmentations called proglottids.  Proglottids originate at the neck of the scolex and mature as they move distally.  Gravid proglottids at the terminal portion of the worm each contain ~50,000 fertilized eggs.  Eggs are released in the stool, which propagates the life cycle (when ingested by pigs) or causes cysticercosis (when ingested by humans), as follows:



  • Pigs (intermediate host) acquire the infection by ingesting eggs in human feces or food contaminated by human feces.  The ova hatch into larvae in the small intestine, invade the bowel wall, and disseminate hematogenously to tissue (eg, striated muscle).  In tissue, the larvae form cysticerci, membranes with fluid and a single invaginated scolex.  Humans who consume the cysticerci in undercooked or raw pork may develop taenasis.
  • Humans (terminal host) who incidentally ingest ova in contaminated food or water may develop cysticercosis.  The ova hatch in the gastrointestinal tract and larvae disseminate hematogenously to tissue (eg, brain, ventricles).  In tissue, the organism forms cysticerci (
    image 1
    ), which generally go through a series of changes over time, as follows:
    • Viable cysts are associated with no or minimal surrounding inflammation.  The organism is protected from the host immune system by active immune-evasion (eg, inhibition of lymphocytes/macrophages) and by the blood-brain barrier (in the case of central nervous system lesions).  Viable cysts have a translucent membrane and a visible scolex.  The parasite may remain in this phase for years.  Viable cysts are generally asymptomatic.
    • Degenerating cysts lose their ability to actively evade the immune system.  The wall of the parasite is invaded by host immune cells, triggering substantial local inflammation and edema, which can cause symptoms.  The cystic fluid becomes cloudy and dense, and the borders become irregular.  Eventually the cyst collapses.
    • Nonviable cysts are marked by calcification of the cyst walls.  Although the parasite in nonviable cysts is dead, calcified cysts in the brain have been associated with continued symptoms of the disease (eg, seizures).


Other Taenia species include T saginata, which is transmitted in undercooked beef (beef tapeworm), and T asiatica, which is transmitted in undercooked pork in Asia (another type of pork tapeworm).  Taenia species have similar life cycles; larvae form cysts in the muscle of intermediate animal hosts (bovine, porcine), and humans acquire the tapeworm by ingesting undercooked or raw meat.  Unlike T solium, they are not associated with cysticercosis.

Clinical presentation

Taeniasis



Patients with pork tapeworm infection are generally asymptomatic and do not notice proglottids shed in stool.  Therefore, they may harbor the tapeworm for months or years without presenting to clinical attention.  Occasionally tapeworms cause nausea, anorexia, or epigastric pain.

Cysticercosis



Manifestations from cysticercosis typically arise 3-5 years after transmission.  Most cases come to clinical attention due to CNS involvement (neurocysticercosis [NCC]), which is classified as follows:



  • Intraparenchymal NCC (~60% of cases)

    • Seizures are the most common presenting symptom of NCC and are usually focal with secondary generalization.  NCC is the most common cause of acquired epilepsy worldwide.
  • Extraparenchymal NCC
    • Intraventricular:  Cysts can lodge in ventricular outflow tracts, leading to hydrocephalus and symptoms of elevated intracranial pressure (eg, nausea, vomiting, headache, vision change) (
      image 2
      ).  In severe cases, patients can develop confusion, focal neurologic deficits, and seizure.
    • Subarachnoid:  This is the most severe form of NCC.  Manifestations are often similar to basilar meningitis (eg, visual field deficits, cranial nerve palsies, focal motor signs, ataxia, stroke).  Fever is generally absent. 
    • Spinal:  Patients usually present with radiculopathy, paresthesia, or sphincter dysfunction.
    • Orbital/ocular:  The extraocular muscles and conjunctiva are most often involved.


Extraneural cysticercosis can also occur.  Although a wide range of tissues can be affected, patients most often develop small (0.5-2 cm), asymptomatic nodules in muscles or subcutaneous tissue.

Diagnosis

Taeniasis



Taeniasis (tapeworm infection) is generally diagnosed by identifying eggs or proglottids in the stool.  Because shedding is intermittent, sensitivity of stool microscopy is low; several stool examinations may be required.  Stool ELISA for T solium antigens or DNA hybridization techniques for eggs in stool can increase sensitivity.

Cysticercosis



Cysticercosis should be suspected in patients who develop adult-onset seizure or signs of elevated intracranial pressure in the setting of potential exposure (eg, endemic area, tapeworm carrier).  Most cases are diagnosed using neuroimaging; if possible, both CT and MRI are performed to maximize visibility of intraparenchymal and extraparenchymal lesions.



Patients with MRI evidence of a scolex within a cystic lesion require no additional testing to confirm the diagnosis (

image 3
).  In contrast, serologic (EITB) or molecular (PCR) testing is required for those who do not have visible evidence of a scolex but do have lesions suggestive of NCC (eg, cysts without a visible scolex, calcifications, enhancing areas).  Lumbar puncture is not generally performed, and brain biopsy is needed only in rare cases when the diagnosis cannot otherwise be established.



All patients with NCC should undergo ophthalmologic evaluation prior to initiation of treatment (treatment can trigger significant inflammation, which can threaten vision).

Differential diagnosis



Intraparenchymal NCC can cause single or multiple enhancing brain lesions, which may resemble the following diseases:



  • Tuberculoma:  Typically causes ring-enhancing brain lesions with significant perilesional edema.  No scolex will be present and cysts at various stages of degeneration will not be seen.  Chest radiography can often identify telltale signs of tuberculosis.  In addition, systemic symptoms and other areas of infection are frequently present. 
  • Toxoplasmosis:  Patients usually have multiple ring-enhancing brain lesions.  Nearly all cases arise in severely immunocompromised hosts.  Although seizure can occur, headache, focal neurologic deficits, and fever are often present.  No scolex or cyst degeneration will be seen.
  • Primary brain tumors:  Can cause a single enhancing brain lesion.  Patients may have seizures but also typically have dull, constant, slowly progressive headaches over weeks or months.

Management

Taeniasis



Although tapeworm infection is generally asymptomatic, eliminating tapeworm carriage reduces risk of cysticercosis in the tapeworm carrier (autoinoculation), household contacts, and the community at large; therefore, it should be prioritized when possible.



  • Praziquantel is the treatment of choice; a single dose is usually curative.
  • Albendazole or niclosamide can be used as alternative agents when praziquantel is not available.  However, the efficacy of treatment may be reduced, and these agents are less studied.

Cysticercosis



Patients with cysticercosis require ophthalmologic evaluation prior to treatment and may require tuberculosis screening should prolonged concurrent corticosteroids be required.  Treatment of cysticercosis is individualized based upon disease manifestations.



  • Antiparasitic therapy:  Required for those with viable or degenerating cysts on neuroimaging unless untreated hydrocephalus or diffuse cerebral edema is present.  Those who only have calcified cysts on neuroimaging do not require antiparasitic treatment.  Albendazole is the treatment of choice and is typically administered for 7-14 days; praziquantel is added to the regimen when â‰¥2 cysts are present.
  • Corticosteroids:  Dexamethasone or prednisone is administered concurrently with antiparasitic treatment to reduce risk of seizures.  It is also typically required for diffuse cerebral edema caused by multiple degrading cysticerci.
  • Antiepileptic drugs:  Antiepileptic drugs are typically administered during antiparasitic treatment.  Treatment is continued for at least 2 years when multiple brain lesions are present.  Some patients require lifelong antiseizure medication. 
  • Surgical intervention:  Patients with elevated intracranial pressure due to obstructive hydrocephalus or ocular lesions often require surgical intervention prior to antiparasitic treatment.

Complications



  • Seizures:  Seizure can continue after treatment or in the setting of calcified cysts.
  • Hydrocephalus:  Ventricular cysts or subarachnoid space involvement can lead to obstructive hydrocephalus.
  • Visual loss:  is secondary to intraocular cysts or retinal involvement.
  • Neurocognitive decline:  Chronic inflammation and scarring from neurocysticercosis can result in cognitive or behavioral changes.

Prognosis



Taeniasis generally resolves with antiparasitic treatment and causes no sequelae.  Neurocysticercosis can be associated with ongoing seizure disorder following treatment; the risk of epilepsy in seropositive individuals is 2-3 times greater than seronegative individuals.  Those with ventricular or subarachnoid involvement are at higher risk for hydrocephalus.

Summary



Taenia solium infection causes 2 distinct infections:



  • Taeniasis (pork tapeworm) occurs when larvae are ingested from contaminated pork.  It is generally asymptomatic.  Diagnosis is usually made with stool microscopy.  Treatment with a single dose of praziquantel is curative. 
  • Cysticercosis (

    ) occurs when eggs are incidentally ingested.  Patients usually present years later with seizures or signs of elevated intracranial pressure.  Diagnosis is made when a cyst with a scolex is identified on neuroimaging; serology may be required when suggestive findings are present but a scolex is not seen.  Treatment is tailored to the disease manifestations but generally includes anti-parasite therapy (eg, albendazole with or without praziquantel), anti-seizure medication, and corticosteroids.  Surgery may be needed when the ventricles or eyes are involved.  Cysticercosis is the leading cause of acquired epilepsy worldwide.


Improved sanitation and the proper cooking of pork can reduce risk of infection.
